meanings.def: to walk with stiff regular steps like a soldier
examples: Quick march! (= the order to start marching)
+ adv./prep. Soldiers were marching up and down outside the government buildings.
+ noun They marched 20 miles to reach the capital.

meanings.def: to walk somewhere quickly in a determined way
examples: She marched over to me and demanded an apology.
Craig marched up to the door and rang the bell.
So saying, she marched boldly out of the house.
Ann marched straight past me and up the stairs.
He marched off, muttering something.
They marched proudly onto the football field.

meanings.def: to walk through the streets in a large group in order to protest about something
examples: Millions of people marched against the war.
They were marching for peace.
We marched peacefully through the streets.
Hundreds of people marched in support of the teachers' pay claim.

meanings.def: to force somebody to walk somewhere with you
examples: The guards marched the prisoner away.
She was marched out of the door and into a waiting car.

meanings.def: to be ordered to leave a place, a job, etc.
to order somebody to leave a place, their job, etc.
to behave in a different way from other people; to have different attitudes or ideas
examples: She was a gifted and original artist who marched to a different drummer.

idioms.def: to be ordered to leave a place, a job, etc.
to order somebody to leave a place, their job, etc.

idioms.idiom: march to (the beat of) a different drummer/drum | march to a different beat/tune
idioms.def: to behave in a different way from other people; to have different attitudes or ideas
examples: She was a gifted and original artist who marched to a different drummer.

related: (as) mad as a hatter/a March hare
march to (the beat of) a different drummer/drum

meanings.def: an organized walk by many people from one place to another, in order to protest about something, or to express their opinions
examples: protest marches
to go on a march
The farmers halted the march outside the Ministry of Agriculture.
The march was broken up by police in riot gear.
There were in excess of 100 000 people at the march.
a march against racism
a march for the victims of the war

meanings.def: an act of marching; a journey made by marching
examples: The army began their long march to the coast.
The army set off on a forced march north.
The border was still a day's march away.
They reached the enemy position after an arduous approach march.
Villages in the army's line of march were burned to the ground.

meanings.def: the steady development or forward movement of something
examples: the march of progress/technology/time
the steady march towards equality

meanings.def: a piece of music written for marching to
examples: a funeral march
The orchestra struck up a military march.
The enemy are on the march.

meanings.def: to gain an advantage over somebody by doing something before them
examples: The company is looking at ways to steal a march on its European competitors.
The enemy are on the march.

idioms.def: to gain an advantage over somebody by doing something before them
examples: The company is looking at ways to steal a march on its European competitors.

meanings.def: the 3rd month of the year, between February and April
examples: She was born in March.
(British English) The meeting is on the fifth of March/​March the fifth.
(North American English) The meeting is on March fifth.
We went to Japan last March.
I arrived at the end of March.
Whale watching trips begin in early March.
The seeds germinate from March to May.
The study appears in the March issue of the Journal of Paediatrics.
The event will be held from March 3rd to 9th.
Elections were held in late March.
He revealed his secret in a March 2019 interview.
He's as mad as a March hare but he does a great job.

idioms.idiom: (as) mad as a hatter/a March hare
examples: He's as mad as a March hare but he does a great job.
